articles.headline: Brazil’s Middle Class Finds a Lifeline at the Pawnshop
articles.snippet: With credit cards charging more than 240 percent interest a year, middle-class Brazilians are increasingly turning to a place where collateral is king.
articles.abstract: With credit cards charging more than 240 percent interest a year, middle-class Brazilians are increasingly turning to a place where collateral is king.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Interest rates in Brazil would make an American loan shark blush. Credit cards charge more than 240 percent a year. Bank loans top 100 percent.

articles.headline: Booyah! Activist Investor Hurls Purple Prose at Jim Cramer
articles.snippet: In a spellbinding letter to Jim Cramer, the activist investor J. Carlo Cannell urged him to cut his pay 70 percent, resign from CNBC and direct his energy to “helping your fellow shareholders crawl back from Hades.”
articles.abstract: In a spellbinding letter to Jim Cramer, the activist investor J. Carlo Cannell urged him to cut his pay 70 percent, resign from CNBC and direct his energy to “helping your fellow shareholders crawl back from Hades.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Activist investors have long used sharply worded letters as weapons in their campaigns to shake up companies. Some, like Daniel S. Loeb, have built fortunes by telling chief executives that they deserve “a well-worn boot planted in the backside.”
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: 17 States Suing on Immigration
articles.snippet: Texas will lead a coalition of 17 states challenging President Obama’s executive actions in federal court.
articles.abstract: Texas will lead a coalition of 17 states challenging President Obama’s executive actions in federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas and 16 other states filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday challenging President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, arguing that he violated his constitutional duty to enforce the laws and illegally placed new burdens on state budgets.
articles.byline: By David Montgomery and Julia Preston

articles.headline: ‘Superbugs’ Kill India’s Babies and Pose an Overseas Threat
articles.snippet: Researchers say a significant share of the bacteria in India — in its water, sewage, animals, soil and even its mothers — are resistant to nearly all antibiotics.
articles.abstract: Researchers say a significant share of the bacteria in India — in its water, sewage, animals, soil and even its mothers — are resistant to nearly all antibiotics.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMRAVATI, India — A deadly epidemic that could have global implications is quietly sweeping India, and among its many victims are tens of thousands of newborns dying because once-miraculous cures no longer work.

articles.headline: Study Finds Violations of Wage Law in New York and California
articles.snippet: The United States Labor Department says that a new study shows that between 3 and 6 percent of all workers in both states are paid less than the minimum wage.
articles.abstract: The United States Labor Department says that a new study shows that between 3 and 6 percent of all workers in both states are paid less than the minimum wage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States Labor Department says that a new study shows that between 3.5 and 6.5 percent of all the wage and salary workers in California and New York are paid less than the minimum wage.

articles.headline: Where 2 Rivers Meet, Visions for Grand Canyon Clash
articles.snippet: A $1 billion plan for hotels, shops and a gondola on the East Rim of the Grand Canyon is the latest in a line of contentious efforts to develop the national landmark.
articles.abstract: A $1 billion plan for hotels, shops and a gondola on the East Rim of the Grand Canyon is the latest in a line of contentious efforts to develop the national landmark.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST RIM OF THE GRAND CANYON, Ariz. — Renae Yellowhorse stood at the edge of the Grand Canyon, 26 bumpy miles across the Painted Desert from the nearest paved road, not a glint of civilization in sight. Ms. Yellowhorse, 52, who has lived her whole life on this Navajo land, cast an arm over the gulf sweeping out to the horizon, pointing to where the Colorado River and the Little Colorado meet in a dazzling burst of deep blue 3,000 feet below.

articles.headline: Putin, Amid Stark Challenges, Says Russia’s Destiny Is in Hand
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin faces renewed unrest in Chechnya and a flailing economy amid continuing tensions with the West.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin faces renewed unrest in Chechnya and a flailing economy amid continuing tensions with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The defining event of Vladimir V. Putin’s initial rise to power was the crushing of an Islamist insurgency in Chechnya, at the cost of human rights abuses and years of dictatorial rule there.

articles.headline: Strong Voice in ‘Fight for 15’ Fast-Food Wage Campaign
articles.snippet: Leading the latest one-day strike, Terrance Wise, who for years has had low-paying fast-food jobs, is at the forefront of a growing movement.
articles.abstract: Leading the latest one-day strike, Terrance Wise, who for years has had low-paying fast-food jobs, is at the forefront of a growing movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Most mornings last year, Terrance Wise left home before his three daughters woke up, to head to his $9.30-an-hour job at Burger King.
